resources.string: We take smoking as a serious issue, below are some other services to help you quit smoking. Click on any service below to be redirected to their website
Smoking is expensive. The amount of money you spend on smoking may surprise you.
Imagine what you could do with that money, you could book a holidays, buy clothes, pay outstanding bills?
Why not open a new savings account or buy a piggy bank to watch your savings grows.
As well as being able to save there are other financial benefits too; you will pay less for health and life insurance and the cost of visiting a doctor.
Upload a motivational video from yourself or someone else to encourage your progress
*One cigarette is equivalent to 1 gram of tobacco
How much you will save over 1 year
How much you save over 1 week
•\tWithin 24 hours: Your chance of a heart attack decreases.
Smoking is the leading cause of preventable death within New Zealand.
When you smoke the chemicals in tobacco reach your lungs very quickly, your blood then carries the toxins to every organ in your body.
When you quit smoking you will lower your risk of death from:

The health benefits of being smokefree start almost immediately. Within 20 minutes of being smokefree your blood pressure, body temperature and pulse rate will drop to normal and within 8 hours your Smoker’s breath disappears, the carbon monoxide level in your blood drops and the oxygen level rises to normal.
Other health benefits and their timescales are:

Being smokefree may assist with your employment as many New Zealand employers are concerned about the health and safety of their workforce and are increasingly encouraging their staff to become smokefree.
Many employers have smokefree policies, which require their buildings and grounds to be smokefree at all times.
Quitting smoking is good for your looks!
•\tYour clothes and hair will smell better
•\tYour fingers and fingernails will no longer look yellow
•\tYou’ll have a better chance for fewer skin wrinkles
If you currently smoke, there are many reasons for you to quit.
There are many rewards of quitting that begin immediately.
Quitting tobacco will not only improve your health but your finances, self-esteem and your everyday life.
Let’s look at some of the motivations you may have to quit smoking.
We shall look at the benefits of being smokefree, some benefits you may not have even thought of:
Quit for the Benefit of Others
By quitting smoking you are protecting those you love.
Smoking not only harms your health but also the health of those around you as exposure to secondhand smoke kills around 350 New Zealanders every year.
Secondhand smoke contains the same poisonous chemicals that you breathe into your body when you smoke.
Children exposed to secondhand smoke are more likely to develop asthma, develop coughs, colds and ear infections.
Children and teenagers whose parents or caregivers smoke are seven times more likely to become smokers themselves.
By being smokefree you should have a longer, healthier life to spend with family, whanau and friends.
We are increasingly expecting places and venues to be smokefree within New Zealand.
There are now many places where people are encouraged to be smokefree to protect others from secondhand smoke and to protect children from exposure to smoking.
There are a number of smokefree places either in place or being considered including playgrounds, beaches, parks and restaurants.
By being smokefree you will no longer need to leave these places for a cigarette or stand outside the venue in the rain and wind!
•\tWithin 48 hours: Your nerve endings start to regroup. Your ability to taste and smell improves.
•\tWithin 3 days: Breathing is easier for you.
•\tWithin 2 to 3 months: Your circulation improves. Walking becomes easier. Your lung capacity increases up to 30 percent.

•\tWithin 1 to 9 months: Sinus congestion and shortness of breath decrease. Cilia that sweep debris from your lungs grow back, increasing your lungs’ ability to handle mucus, clean the lungs, and reduce infection. Your energy increases.
•\tWithin 1 year: Your excess risk of coronary disease is half that of a person who smokes.
•\tWithin 2 years: Your heart attack risk drops to near normal.

•\tWithin 5 years: Lung cancer death rate for the average former pack-a-day smoker decreases by almost half. Your risk of having a stroke reduces. Your risk of developing mouth, throat, and esophageal cancer is half that of a smoker.
•\tWithin 10 years: Lung cancer death rate is similar to that of a person who does not smoke. The precancerous cells are replaced.
•\tWithin 15 years: Your risk of coronary heart disease is the same as a person who has never smoked.
Select date you\'ve quit or planning to quit smoking
Please let us know why you are using this application. You can select more than one.
What date have you or plan to quit? E.g 16 Feb 2016
For users that have the aid of Nicotine Replacement Treatment, this will help notify you when to take your treatment
How long does your treatment last?
To remove notifications, set the frequency to 0
